Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 07:47AM barb3246 wrote: I'm a little confused. Should you always get a 2nd opinion on pathology slides, or only in certain circumstances?  Is it common to have a significantly different diagnosis after a 2nd opinion?
Posts.Title: 2nd opinion: Pathology? EleanorJ misheley

Posts.Content: barb3246 wrote: The radiologist who did my 2 core-needle biopsies last week was nice enough to call me with the results, and both were benign!! I am so glad that I took the advice of a lot of ladies on this forum and got my results over the phone instead of waiting for my follow-up appt. with my breast surgeon on the 17th!!  Today is my birthday, and it was the best birthday present I ever got! I am just so relieved, and I want to thank everyone for their kind words and best wishes - you are a great group of women!! The lump in my left breast was a fibroadenoma, and the right was a papilloma (I think he said there were a couple of them), which was causing the discharge that started this whole mess. The radiologist wants me to come back for a follow-up MRI in 3-6 months - is this typical for benign results? He also said that my breast surgeon may want to remove more tissue around the biopsy sites, so I guess I'll find out about that on the 17th. I'm hoping she won't suggest more surgery, but I will do whatever needs to be done. Do surgeons usually remove more tissue around benign tumors? My breast surgeon had told me that her hospital would do a pathology review of the biopsies since they were done at a different hospital. Could the results be read very differently by 2 pathologists? I sure hope not, I don't want any surprises on the 17th....  Barb Barb Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I Got My Biopsy Results barb3246 leaf

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 06:02AM barb3246 wrote: Yes, you should tell the BS. I'm really surprised that they didn't schedule your MRI around your period.  I've had over half a dozen breast MRIs in the last 2 years, and ALL of them were scheduled around my period. They like to schedule them between days 7-14 usually (I have had them done at 2 major Boston hospitals).  My understanding is that if its not timed right it can be more difficult to read and may result in more false positives due to hormones, etc.
Posts.Title: MRI and period timing... marie5890 marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2009 12:42PM barb3246 wrote: No, it does NOT definitely mean you have BC. I had clear spontaneous discharge from my nipple as well, and I had 2 biopsies on it - both were B9 papillomas.  You should definitely get it checked out though. Barb

I recently had an excisional biopsy for atypia and radial scar, also B9.  Its very scary, but there is a good chance it will be B9.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 08:24AM barb3246 wrote: Don't panic yet - it may be just a papilloma, which is a benign wart-like growth in the milk ducts near the nipple. They cause a clear/yellow discharge. I had a clear discharge, and the biopsy showed a papilloma.

I was told by the radiologist and my breast surgeon that these were all benign findings with no need for further surgery.  I just need to get a 6-month follow-up MRI to check on everything.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 12:45PM barb3246 wrote: I am now waiting to get a stereotactic biopsy for microcalcifications in my left breast, and I'm scared to death.  I am now also worried that I should have had the papillomas in the right breast excised, even though my breast surgeon said not necessary.  I am just so overwhelmed right now I don't know what to do.  Hopefully I will get benign results from my next biopsy, and then I may go get a 2nd opinion about everything that has happened in this past year.  What would I need to bring to a 2nd opinion?  Why would my doc say no excision required if everyone else seems to think its necessary?   I think I am losing confidence in my docs, and its not a good feeling. I don't know how to deal with all this stress.....
Posts.Title: Biopsy b9 but still excision? sheila1951 barb3246

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 09:49AM barb3246 wrote: I also was diagnosed with a radial scar by 1 pathologist. I got a 2nd opinion, and the other pathologist did not see the radial scar at all. I had an excisonal biospy of the area anyways, and all it showed was a small bit of atypia. My BS told me that less than 10% of radial scars are associated with cancer, so try not to worry too much.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2010 10:22PM barb3246 wrote: Hi Jen, I feel your pain. I recently had an excisional biopsy, and the morning of the surgery my surgeon tells me that she's going to Mexico on vacation for 2 weeks, so I can get my results when she got back. Well I flipped out and told her I could NOT wait that long, so she told me I could call her nurse and get the results over the phone, which I got 5 days later.  I would have been a basket-case if I had to wait that long. You are definitely entitled to get your results in a timely manner.  My results were B9 - I'm hoping the same for you!! Barb
Posts.Title: two different biopsys needed - both sides jdfnj jdfnj

Posts.Content: barb3246 wrote: Has anyone ever had their MRI re-read and get a different/worse result or BIRADS rating? I am having all of my prior MRIs re-read by the radiologists at Dana Farber/Brigham & Women's hospital in Boston, and I am worried that they will find something worse on my MRIs. I am transferring over my care to the High Risk Clinic there, and they re-read all films and pathology results for all new patients. All of my prior MRIs have noted multiple "foci of enhancement" in both breasts that they have been following (BIRADS 3), and I was told to get a follow-up MRI in 6 months after my latest one. I guess I have just lost confidence in the breast clinic that I have been going to, and am scared that they missed something. They told me it could take a couple of weeks for them to re-read all of the films, and I am getting really stressed thinking about what the new radiologists might find. I am so scared that I'll need yet another biopsy (I've already had 6!!) that I'm having trouble sleeping and have a knot in my stomach. Thanks for listening and understanding. Barb Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: MRI shows linear enhancement Alli shabby6485

Posts.Content: barb3246 wrote: My breast surgeon is at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, and this is where I also get my breast exams and mammograms. I have been seeing her for 10 years since I started high-risk screening at 35. I started getting breast MRIs 2 years ago, and have since had 5 or 6, and a total of 6 B9 biopsies. I have been getting the MRIs, however, at a different hospital, St. Elizabeth's, because at the time I needed my 1st biopsy 2 years ago, Tufts was not equipped to perform MRI-guided biopsies, so I was sent to St. Elizabeth's for them. Since then I have had several MRIs and 2 MRI-guided biopsies at St. E's, all done by the same radiologist, who I really like. She is very personable and reassuring, and has no problem answering my many questions. After my latest biopsy (excisional at Tufts), my breast surgeon suggested that I now get my MRIs at Tufts, since they have hired a new radiologist who specializes in breast MRIs and MRI-guided biopsies. She explained that it would be easier to have all of my films and reports in 1 location, instead of having to have the reports and CDs copied and sent from St. E's to Tufts each time. It would also be easier for her having the radiologist at the same hospital instead of having to talk over the phone. I haven't met this new radiologist, but my BS said that she is very good at what she does, and will explain procedures and answer patient questions. I was somewhat hesitant, especially when she also added that the downside was that there could be some slight variations when using different MRI machines, as well as a different radiologist interpreting the results. The radiologist at St. E's is following some "enhancements" in both breasts, and I need to have my next MRI in July. My breast surgeon told me that it was my decision as to where to have it done. I'm not sure if I should stick with the radiologist at St. E's since I like her, she is familiar with my past MRIs, and the machine will be the same. Or should have them done at Tufts where at least all of my reports, films and doctors will be in one place and available to all of my doctor's there, but where some questions may arise due to the change in MRI equipment and radiologist interpretation. What would you ladies do? It is really stressing me out to have to decide, and I want to make the right decision. Barb Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What Would You Do ? Need Opinions Please barb3246 LISAMG

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 11:48AM barb3246 wrote: Thanks for the replies. Jen - I didn't think about it that way - I guess it would be like getting a second opinion, which may be a good thing. I think I'm a little scared that the new machine might make the MRI look different from prior ones, setting me up for yet another biopsy :(    But a second set of eyes can't hurt. Anne - The consistency of having everything at 1 facility is mainly why I am leaning towards that option. Yes, if I choose to have my MRIs at the same hospital as my mammos/breast exams, I will definitely need to have all my prior MRI films sent from the other hospital. I assume CD copies of the films are adequate? Barbe1958 - You are definitely right about the mental anguish. Sometimes I felt like I was having a nervous breakdown, and I feel like I've aged 10 years in the past 2 years. Stress will definitely take a toll. I swear I have post traumatic stress disorder from all of this.  I have considered going to an entirely new facility (such as Mass General) but I am just nervous about starting all over with a new team that is not familiar with my complicated history. Your comment about being screened better.... what would you suggest ? I have never been given an ultrasound (not sure why), but I am currently getting alternating mammos and MRIs, and breast exams. My BS said I could stop the MRIs if I wanted to since I've had so many B9 biopsies, but I think I'd be more nervous doing that, since all of my mammos have never shown anything. Barb

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2010 08:26AM barb3246 wrote: Kam28 - Yes, so far I am happy with Dana Farber.  You can call their High Risk Breast Clinic and they will tell you how to transfer your care over to them.  They will also assign you to a doctor.  I saw Dr. Judy Garber, who is an oncologist and head of the High Risk Clinic.  She was very nice, as were everyone else I met so far.  They will definitely give you a 2nd opinion on your mammos and MRI - in fact its required.  They will also re-do any pathology from biopsies/surgery. Mawhinney - thanks for the reply. That's exactly why I transferred my care over to Dana Farber/B&W - because I think their staff is more experienced with dealing with breast health and breast imaging.  But like you said, another set of eyeballs may note something that the first reviewer didn't notice, and that's exactly what scares me!!  Sandie - I'm so glad that it turned out well for you and you didn't need another biopsy!  I hope the same happens for me !!  Barb

Posts.Title: So who is waiting for test results/ or having test Tenmom Kimberly5307

Posts.Content: barb3246 wrote: I had a ultrasound-guided core-needle biopsy last Oct because I had been having a clear spontaneous discharge from my right nipple. The radiologist took several samples and placed a clip in the area. The biopsy came back negative - papilloma with no atypical cells. There was residual enhancement in the area after this biopsy in Oct (birads 3 on post-biopsy MRI), so I had a 3 month followup MRI in January. That MRI just noted the biopsy clip and said that the hematoma at the biopsy site had greatly diminished. This MRI was given a BIRADS rating of 3A, and I was told to come back for another followup MRI in 6 months. I have since been experiencing some occasional clear discharge from that nipple, but much less than before the biopsy. I had the 6-month followup MRI last week, and I just got a call from my breast surgeon. She said that the radiologist is still seeing abnormal enhancement in the area (BIRADS 4), and she now wants to do an MRI-guided biopsy. She said that the area may not have been "adequately sampled" during the last biopsy. I am so worried and upset, I can barely function. I'm at work, and I really can't concentrate on anything, and I jump every time the phone rings. I'm very scared that they missed something bad back in Oct. and it has been growing there ever since. What are the chances that the radiologist who did the first biopsy missed an invasive cancer?? Could there possibly be more papillomas growing in the area that were missed and that's whats enhancing? Do I still have an 80% chance of this being benign? My mother passed away from breast cancer, so its very difficult for me to not think the worst.  Any words of advice or reassurance? Barb Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 01:56PM barb3246 wrote: Hi Sheila, Yes, the way they do it at Tufts Medical Center in Boston is that they have a board made up of BC specialists review the pathology results in a weekly meeting held early on Tues mornings, and then the breast surgeon discusses the results with you afterwards.  I wish I could just get someone to call me back before the weekend. I mentioned my anxiety about the wait to the radiologist, but he just said he really couldn't help.  I'm torn though - I want to know as soon as possible if its B9, but if not, maybe its better to hear it from the breast surgeon in person ???  Even in person, I think I would collapse if I got bad news. I really don't think I could deal with it. I'm not a strong person, and I'm a pessimist by nature,so I'm sure I'd just fall apart and not be able to fight this terrible disease or get on with my life without living in constant fear.
Posts.Title: Just Back From Stereotactic Biopsy barb3246 Leah_S

Posts.Content: barb3246 wrote: It went pretty well. It was a bit painful, but not too bad. I think they didn't use enough novocaine, because I could feel the incision and the vacuum sampling. It was over quick though - the whole thing took less than 45 minutes.  I saw the images after they scanned the biopsy cores, and the radiologist thinks he got all the calcifications, so that's good.  After the mammo, he had told me that the calcs were round, but today on the screen they looked very irregular shaped to me, so that has me more worried. He just said we'd have to wait for the pathology to know anything for sure. So now I have to wait until next Tuesday for the results.    I don't know how I'm going to get thru the next 5 days without ending up in a looney bin!!  Time to go rest and start icing down the boob....
